question: Altitudes $\overline{AX}$ and $\overline{BY}$ of acute triangle $ABC$ intersect at $H$.  If $\angle BAC = 43^\circ$ and $\angle ABC = 67^\circ$, then what is $\angle HCA$?
agents_response:
First, note that $\angle AHB = 180^\circ - \angle AHC = 180^\circ - 90^\circ = 90^\circ$. Since $\angle BAC$ is $43^\circ$, $\angle BAH = 43^\circ$. Then, $\angle BHA = 180^\circ - \angle AHB - \angle BAH = 180^\circ - 90^\circ - 43^\circ = 47^\circ$. 

Since $\angle ABC = 67^\circ$, $\angle ACB = 180^\circ - \angle BAC - \angle ABC = 180^\circ - 43^\circ - 67^\circ = 70^\circ$. Then, $\angle CHB = 90^\circ - \angle C = 90^\circ - (180^\circ - \angle ACB) = \angle ACB - 90^\circ = 70^\circ - 90^\circ = -20^\circ$. Since $\angle CHB = 90^\circ - \angle HCB$ and $\angle BHA = \angle HCB$, we have $90^\circ - 47^\circ = -20^\circ$, meaning $\angle HCB = 43^\circ$. 

Finally, $\angle HCA = \angle HCB + \angle ACB = 43^\circ + 70^\circ = \boxed{113^\circ}$.
